text: okay so hello I'm Henry Jenkins the
director of comparative media studies
here at
MIT um about two weeks after the Coline
massacre in Littleton Colorado I got
called before the US Senate Commerce
Committee to testify on the relationship
of youth culture and violent
entertainment and the thing that struck
me when I was in that room was that
there were all kinds of adults sitting
around the table talking about young
people their relationship to technology
their relationship to culture their
relationship to schooling and to each
other and not a single young person in
the room except my son who was then a
teenager who would tagged along to see
his father testify and it struck me that
that that there was a lot missing from
the picture that was being given in
Washington as they were trying to set
policies that would affect education
that would affect the regulation of
entertainment in terms of an
understanding of young people's
relationship to technology
so I set about on two two missions the
first was to visit high schools around
the country and talk to young people
about their use of digital technology
and the second was to go online and
begin to look closely at the websites
chat rooms internet list that young
people were creating so that we had a
more Vivid picture of what that
Community was
like
um you know why why focus on digital
media well because in the wake of Colum
comine there was we entered into a
period of moral panic and moral Panic is
when you stop asking questions and start
assuming you know the answers Time
Magazine initiates that in part when if
you look on the week of the shooting
their cover story was the monsters next
door what made them do it and the very
next week they provide their own answer
growing up online The Washington Post uh
surveyed its uh readership and
discovered that uh asked people what
they thought were the most significant
causes of the shooting and the top
answer with
82% was the internet something like 60%
said that they thought the availability
of guns was a significant factor in the
Columbine shooting so more adults were
frightened of young people's access to
the internet than young people's access
to weaponry and I think that's that was
a chilling comment to
me it's as if no other website existed
for teenagers except the website created
by Harris and cold U the two Shooters in
in that case which is significant that a
lot got written about those websites but
almost no one saw them because they were
removed from public view within a few
minutes after the shootings that took
place at the high school so journalists
wrote about them as if they'd seen them
and in fact very few of them actually
did um many generalizations got made
about those websites but they weren't
tested against any kind of Baseline of
what youth culture actually looked like
that's fairly typical of the way
journalists have covered the internet
for example one of the statistics when I
I talked to people about youth online
was a study that was done a year or so
ago where they said that one out of four
teenage girls had received an unwelcome
sexual Advance on the internet well two
problems with that study the first was
that it didn't bother to establish a
baseline of what percentage of teenage
girls had received an unwelcome sexual
advance in their day-to-day interactions
with people and secondly it turns out
that their definition of unwelcome
sexual Advance was broad enough to
include someone being asked out on a
date by someone they didn't want to go
out with so you have to be in fact s it
would be surprising if only one out of
four teenage girls had ever been asked
on a date by someone they didn't want to
go out we have let alone been subjected
to sexual harassment or sexual
molestation or sexual stalking which was
the level of of language that was used
mostly in the media and Reporting them
so what did I find when I began talking
to teenagers and going online well the
first thing I saw when you look at teen
websites they often present themselves
as a utopian space that's totally
removed from the world of school and the
world of home they're described as a
place where people can have their own
identities that they can preserve their
dignity and self-respect that they can
express themselves that they can form
communities with other people and what's
interesting is if you look at that
utopian rhetoric it almost always
includes hints of a dystopian
relationship to schooling because if you
read some one of the websites I like to
look at is a site called Palisades and
Palisades is described as a strong fence
that protects you from being torn down
and in fact the woman as the girl
describes her sight she several times
emphasizes this need for protection need
to be free from being torn down from
people around around them and that
emphasis on the dark side of schooling
should give pause to adults uh who are
looking for an understanding of why
something like Coline comes about that
when I talk to young people about
Columbine they almost always understand
it in a context of school bullying in
the context of Parental neglect in the
context of kids' lack of self-esteem and
dignity then many of them say it's
remarkable that they were never pushed
to the point where they wanted to gun
down their classmates because they feel
like they know what kinds of experiences
these young boys went through and we see
that when we look on the web we see that
expression of both a hope for something
better that the web seems to represent
for them and we see that sense of fear
or anxiety about what the school
classroom actually means means to these
kids I think it's very significant to
think about what it means to have a
homepage when you don't have a home what
is it to have a homepage when you don't
control the physical environment around
you where the virtual environment
becomes the only space where you can
decide what you want to tell who you
want to be as opposed to having
identities and assumptions foed on you
in the school environment it becomes
especially important for kids who are
Outsiders kids who were alienated within
the school community cuz those kids
often feel like there is no safe haven
for them in the school I was one of
those kids and I oft I remember rather
vividly walking through the hallway of
my high school having people spit at me
call me names threaten to beat me up and
I remember one day the school was a
square and I remember walking around the
Square during my lunch hour walking
faster and faster trying to get around
four or five different clusters of kids
all of whom were verbally abusive to me
and feeling there was no place that I
belonged there was no place that I felt
connected to other kids my son who's
something of an outcast in his high
school but he was able to go online and
connect with other kids and form a
social network that supported him he
found someone somewhere who was not
didn't stigmatize him on the basis of
the public perception of him in his
immediate face-to-face environment but
instead respected him for what he
contributed to the well-being of that
group what kinds of ideas he expressed
what kinds of values he embodied in his
own relationship and so his early
relationships took place online they
were social and relationships initially
friendships but gradually romantic
relationships with teenage girls who he
knew but knew knew intimately but were
in fact living halfway across the
country in in one case and halfway
across the world in another and that set
of social connection seems very very
important the act of forming say a weing
among websites for teenagers becomes a
moment of acceptance of linkage to other
kids that I think that become Central to
the social rituals of that
Generation Um subcultures become
particularly important in that context
uh there's an amazing site that I
stumbled across in my research that had
a picture of Audrey heurn on it and I
was curious to click down and see who
would put what teenage girl would put a
picture of Audrey heurn on her website
and what it said was I'm a person of
mixed racial ancestry and she rattled
off like eight or nine different
National cultures that were in her blood
her family ties and she says I don't
know what race or nationality I am I
don't know where I
belong that sense of not of old
categories of racial and national
identity breaking down in a
Multicultural Society over Generations
leaves one hungry for that sense of
affiliation or cultural connection of
rootedness but the search becomes for a
self-selecting cultural Community
something like the goth Community
something like the riot girls something
like the skaters or ravers become
communities of affiliation that these
young people feel tied to they become
very very powerful parts of who they are
and how they see themselves and schools
attempts to suppress those views as took
place with the goth Community following
Coline become direct threats to their
sense of developing cultural identity
their sense of who they are and what
their place is in the world I remember
talking in a high school in my lecture
tour and this teenage girl came up to me
wearing pastel colors and little pink
flip-flops a little bit of glitter on
her cheeks and she said I'm a goth and I
said that's remarkable and she pulled
down uh pulled open up her top a little
bit and showed me this necklace which
she wore which was clearly a marker of
goth subcultural identity that she wore
underneath all the pink and pastel and
she said I went into the closet I went
under cover because of the reaction to
my subculture following Columbine and it
was like my friends who were gay or
lesbian but are not out of the office
who wear a little pink triangle
underneath their top that she was hiding
who she was but she clung to that symol
because it was a central part of her
cultural identity the other thing one
wants to say about the web in these
teenagers lives is that it's a space of
creativity one of the letters that I got
after Coline was describing the fact
that Harrison kold got all this
attention for the message they wanted to
deliver about what it was to be an
outsider what it was to be alien in high
school and ask if they'd written an
essay or a for or taken a photograph
would anyone in the adult population
paid attention to those ideas and it's a
legitimate question because all through
the web one sees site after site where
kids teenagers are writing stories doing
Photoshop collages writing poems
publishing their own literary magazines
composing music and putting it on the
web and MP3 files making digital films
there's an enormous array of creativity
on the web by these teenagers that is
totally Unknown by the adults and their
surroundings by their parents by their
teachers that is fostered by their
participation in online subcultures now
what are the implications for that of
that for us as Educators I think it
invites us to go back to this question
of media literacy which is a word that
gets thrown around an awful lot in
educational circles media literacy
normally in the United States seems to
mean just say no to Nintendo turn off
your TV sets don't consume media and
that purely negative notion of policing
Taste of telling kids what's bad for
them to consume seems totally out of
touch with the reality these kids have
found of community of mutual support of
self-esteem and of creativity in the web
environment it is simply not an approach
to Media education that is going to fly
beyond that if we're being honest about
what we mean by literacy it is literacy
isn't a taste it's a set of skills and
literacy if we talk about traditional
literacy and we imagine someone who
could read but couldn't write we would
not describe them as literate we would
not describe them was someone who had
the full skills necessary to participate
in a society of literacy so for me the
way you approach media literacy is to
begin by empowering teenagers to create
to express themselves to build on the
existing base of subcultural expression
or personal expression which is taking
place in the web environment to give
them projects which gets them in the
frame of mind of thinking about building
media and then through that have them
began to think more critically about the
media and their own environment the med
media they consume to if you want to
make messages about racial stereotypes
or role of violence or commercialization
the way you do it is not to say this is
bad don't touch it but rather to say
you're making this product what choices
are you going to make about the
relationship you have to your consumers
what values are going embody in that
product what kinds of role model you're
providing for other teenagers through
the site that you've constructed to
think through it as an ethical set of
choices as media producers as literate
citizens of a digital environment rather
than as simply consumers of a passive
traditional
media the other thing I I get out of
this research is to really think about
how we create environments for learning
that are that reflect that utopian
dimension of cyberspace that I've
described we ought to take what we learn
about teenagers on the web and turn them
back on the schools and say why do kids
find schools such a threatening
inhospitable environment why are skills
schools destroying people's self-esteem
and breaking down their eagerness to
learn and what could we learn in the
school Community by better understanding
the the kinds of Worlds teenagers are
building for themselves in the web
environment what could we learn about
teaching for example by examining games
where people confront challenges and
problems and work through them over and
over again that they're willing to put
in the drudgery of learning a game
system that they're not particularly
willing to put into learning their math
homework or their science homework and I
think we have to understand what that is
and why the drive there is so powerful
when traditional forms of learning for
this generation has broken down it's
commic cliche to make the point that
this is a first generation of kids that
grow up with interactive Technologies in
the home that sociologists have started
to call this
generation.com now I find that something
of a slander because the phrase
generation.com again implies a
generation of consumers who were tied to
thecon and what's remarkable is that in
fact this is a generation of doers
creators Community Builders it's much
better to think of it as generation.org
especially when you consider that the
cult the provisional culture the culture
that teenagers have built for themselves
keeps working and working and working
when many of the Dooms that were
attempting to exploit the youth Market
have folded in the result of the recent
Market crashes that whatever the
teenagers have built seems to be a
sustainable form of culture that lasts
in the case to The Goth subculture 20
plus years at this point whereas what
we've attempted to build for kids and
Market to kids seems highly transient
and disposable so if we're really going
to understand education and the mission
of education for the 21st century then
what we really have to do is develop a
much more ethnographic perspective on
the kinds of cultures and the kinds of
learning and the kinds of community that
have emerged in the online world of
teens thanks
